journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A practical real-time non-uniform rational B-spline curve interpolator for computer numerical control machining

article-meta.aff: 1Shenzhen Graduate School, Harbin Institute of Technology, HIT Campus Shenzhen University Town, Shenzhen, People’s Republic of China
2Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Kowloon, Hong Kong, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *Shenzhen Graduate School, Harbin Institute of Technology, HIT Campus Shenzhen University Town, Shenzhen, People’s Republic of China. email: Jiangang_lee@163.com

abstract.p: Non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) interpolator, a key technique in computer numerical control (CNC) machining, has many advantages over linear and circular interpolator. A practical real-time NURBS interpolator based on an off-line algorithm, which is developed to handle the limitation of velocity and acceleration, is presented in this article. Two processing modules are employed to realize the real-time interpolator. In one module, a NURBS curve is split into shorter NURBS curves or approximated as continuous line segments according to the minimum splitting length first, and then the velocity planning of a short curve is applied. Inthe other module, the interpolation according to the velocity planning results is implemented. The proposed algorithm realizes the real-time velocity planning and interpolation of a NURBS curve regardless of the curve length or the continuity. It is also applicable to three-dimensional surface designed by computer-aided design system, which is composed of multiple NURBS curves or both NURBS curves and continuous line segments. Both the simulation and experiment results have proved the effectiveness of the proposed practical real-time NURBS interpolator.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In computer numerical control (CNC) systems, demand for modelling freeform profiles designed bycomputer-aided design/computer-aided manufacturing (CAD/CAM) systems keeps increasing. As the conventional CNC systems only provide linear and circular interpolators, the parametric curves must be converted into a huge number of small linear and circular segments based on predefined chord accuracy in CAM systems. Then, the approximated curve is processed by the interpolator to generate motion commands for machining.

The parametric interpolator converts the parametric curve designed in CAD/CAM systems to the servo-command of the CNC machine tools. Ithas recently been acknowledged as an alternative to replace these conventional linear and circular interpolators, especially for high-speed and high-accuracy machining. In this regard, it is necessary to develop the parametric interpolator.

Non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) curve [1], a type of parametric curves, has been favoured in CAD systems for a long time, as it offers a common mathematical formulation to represent both the standard analytic-form and free-form shapes. Therefore, the NURBS interpolator is the most popular parametric interpolator.

In the recent years, many kinds of NURBS interpolation methods have been proposed in the literature. At first, the Taylor first-order and second-order approximation approaches [2], the speed-controlled interpolation algorithm [3], and Runge–Kutta methods [4] are developed, in which the derivative of NURBS curve has to be computed directly, and the speed error cannot be evaluated. Then, the predictor–corrector interpolator (PCI) [5] is proposed, in which the error deviation can be evaluated and corrected by the user. After that, the path interpolation method [6] is presented, in which only the first derivative is needed. After that, a robust Taylor-expansion-based NURBS interpolator [7] is proposed, in which the extreme knot distribution is considered. The adaptive-feed rate algorithm with confined chord-errors of NURBS curve [6] is proposed, in which a circular approximation to restraint the relationship of chord-error and velocity is used. In Ref. [8], an algorithm, which is able to limit the acceleration and deceleration within the machine tool capacity, is proposed. An off-line algorithm of a continuous NURBS curve, which can handle both chord-error and acceleration/deceleration limitation, is presented [9]. The idea of curve splitting at the C0 continuity point [6] is proposed to compute the path length. Acontour error analysis and feed rate adjustment NURBS curve interpolator [10] is presented. The implementation of a CNC NURBS curve interpolator based on control of speed and precision [11] is proposed. A method to compute curvature minimum and parametric curves maximum (represented in NURBS format) [12] is presented. A real-time adaptive NURBS interpolator considering the acceleration anddeceleration capacity for each individual axis is developed to confine both the chord-error and the axis acceleration [13] is presented, where a look-ahead window is utilized to improve the calculation performance for real-time application.

All these algorithms mentioned above have just considered single NURBS curve, but the tool-path may contain two or more NURBS curves. Besides, the big angle may exist at the joint point of two curves while simple NURBS curve interpolator cannot deal with these kinds of curves. What is more, the algorithm is not applicable if the velocity planning and the interpolation are employed separately.

In this article, a practical real-time NURBS curve interpolator with data buffer and two processing modules is proposed. One processing module is used to achieve tool-path preprocessing and velocity planning. Long NURBS curve will be split into short NURBS curves according to minimum splitting length first. Then, the suitable velocity planning method will be used for each NURBS curve. If the length of one NURBS curve or the distance between two cusps of a NURBS curve is less than minimum splitting length, this segment curve will be approximated as short continuous line segments according to the minimum chord-error limitation,and then the look-ahead method will be used for the velocity planning of short continuous line segments. The results data of velocity planning will be stored in the data buffer tentatively. The other module is used to realize interpolation according to the velocity planning results of the first module. Three-dimensional (3D) interpolation points in every sampling period will be computed and sent to the control loop. Two requirements should be satisfied to ensure the real-time requirement of NURBS interpolator. First, two modules should be executed at the same time. When the velocity planning for one or more (not the whole tool-path) short curves is finished in the first module, the results in thedata buffer will be sent to the second module to compute the interpolation points, and this procedure will not finish until the end of the tool-path. Second, the length of each short curve is short enough and the computing time is less than the machining time.

The rest of this article is organized as follows. In Section 2, a brief introduction of the NURBS curve and the basic idea of real-time NURBS interpolator are given. In Section 3, the tool-path preprocessing is discussed in detail. The velocity planning is proposed in Section 4, and the interpolation in Section 5. Section 6 provides simulation and experiment results and Section 7 concludes this article.

sec.title: 2 THE NURBS CURVE AND REAL-TIME INTERPOLATOR
sec.p: The NURBS curve’s representation is (1) where (n + 1) is the number of control points and p the degree, {Pi} the control points, and {Wi} the corresponding weights of control points. The recursive formula for Ni,p(u) is (2) where ui are the so-called knots forming a knot vector U = {u0, u1,…, up, up+1,…, um−p−1, um−p,…, um−1, um} and u0 = u1 =…= up, um−p = …= um−1 = um. The degree, number of knots, and number of control points are related by the formula m = n + p + 1. ANURBS curve can be determined uniquely if control points, weights, and knot vector are given.

The interpolation is the computation of next parameter uj+1 at next sampling period. If the current parameter uj, velocity Vj, and sampling time Ts are known, it can be determined by the following formula (3) where Δuj is the incremental value of parameter.
PCI method [5] is used in this article to make the velocity deviation controllable. The initial value u∧j+1 of next parameter can be computed by a simple formula (4)

Then, an iterative procedure [4] is used to determine the final value of next parameter uj+1 (5) where Vj is the desired velocity command at ui, V∧j the predicted velocity command, and β a correctional coefficient. The terminated condition is (6) where ɛ is a specified tolerance of the velocity error.

The velocity planning and the interpolation are two main procedures of a curve interpolator. If these twoprocedures are performed at the same time, the processing efficiency can be enhanced greatly. Besides, the motion can be monitored and the right position information can be returned if the machining is interrupted for some reasons.

The concepts of data buffer and two disposing modules are introduced in this section, as shown in Fig. 1. The long initial NURBS curve C0 will be split into two NURBS curves as C1 and C2. When the velocity planning of the first curve C1 is finished, the results are stored in the data buffer, and then the interpolation module will get data from this buffer. The buffer will keep non-empty as the second curve C2 will take the place of initial curve C0, and continue to split curve and send data to the buffer. The whole procedures of curve splitting, velocity planning, and interpolation will not stop until the end of tool-path. Fig. 1
The realization process of the real-time NURBS interpolator

The complete flow chart of the practical real-time NURBS interpolator is shown in Fig. 2, where Vi is the velocity planning results of current curve Ci and Vi+1 the velocity planning results of next curve Ci+1. Fig. 2
The complete flaw chart of the practical real-time NURBS interpolator

sec.title: 3 THE TOOL-PATH PREPROCESSING
sec.p:
The tool-path preprocessing is the first step of the interpolator. The whole process is shown in Fig. 3, where S is the length of the whole tool-path, Si the length from the first point to the first cusp, Si+1 the length of the second curve after splitting, Smin theminimum splitting length, and Smin ' the splitting length, which is a value greater than or equal to the minimum splitting length Smin. Fig. 3
The program flow chart of tool-path preprocessing

The tool-path preprocessing contains the following processes: defining the splitting length, finding the discontinuous points, splitting NURBS curve, and writing NURBS curve into small continuous line segments.

If the NURBS curve is very short, the velocity planning of one curve will relate to the curve before it and after it, i.e. the modification of velocity planning results cannot be completed in one curve, and the adjacent curve will be affected. In order to guarantee that the velocity planning of current curve is independent of the other curves, the length of short NURBS curve after splitting should be ensured. It is defined as following (7) where Vmax and Amax are the allowed maximum velocity and acceleration defined according to the machine performance, respectively and Smin a minimum length for achieving once-complete accelerating and decelerating processes.

It is time-consuming if the interpolation will not start until the velocity planning of the whole curve finishes when a NURBS curve is very long. In addition, the first derivative does not exist if there is a sharp corner in the NURBS curve, while the velocity planning needs NURBS curve’s curvature, as shown in Fig. 4. Therefore, the curve splitting is essential for a real-time curve interpolator.
Case 1: The point where the curvature is needed is at the cusp. As the first and second derivatives do not exist, the curvature is incomputable.
Case 2: The cusp is skipped, i.e. the cusp will beignored when computing the curvature. As the velocity is determined by the limitation of curvature, the velocity planning results will be obviously incorrect.
Fig. 4
Two cases in computing curvature of NURBS curve

Curve splitting determines new knot vectors, control points, and weights of the two new NURBS curves after splitting, which should make the newcurves keeping the same sharp with the old one. It can be realized by inserting knots in the definitional domain of NURBS curve. Define the control pointsPi(i=0,1,…,n) of a p degree NURBS curve,split this curve into two curves at u¯=[uk,uk+1]∈[up,un+1], and take u¯ as an insert knot in the knot vector U=[u0,u1,…,un+p+1]. When the insert number is p − r, the knot vector is (8) where r is the multiplicity time of a knot.

If ui=u¯, it means u¯ is an existing knot. The knotneeds to be inserted v = p - r times to reach the multiplicity p. Otherwise, u¯ is not an existing knot. The knot needs to be inserted v = p times to reach the multiplicity p. When a knot is inserted, new control points of this curve will be computed. In this case, the unique middle vertex of last computation is the curve splitting point.

The short NURBS curve is defined as follows: in oneNURBS curve, if there are two or more cusps (start and end points are also considered as cusps), and the curve of two adjacent cusps is shorter than minimum splitting length, the curve between the two cusps is named short NURBS curve. The method of NURBS velocity planning will not be suitable for this kind of NURBS curve. The curve will be written into short continuous line segments within the given chord-error.

A simple algorithm will be used to achieve it. Insert some parameters in equal step length (9) where d is the step length. After inserting, these 3D points on NURBS curve of the inserting parameter can be computed. Ermax is defined as the maximum chord-error, and Erj is the computed chord-error of adjacent point uj, uj+1. If Erj>Ermax, the middle point u~j,j+1=(uj+uj+1)/2 will be inserted, and the corresponding chord-error will be computed as well. If Erj≤Ermax, the current chord-error is within the limitation, the chord-error of the next two parameters will be computed. The iteration algorithm will not stop until all chord-errors are less than or equal to the maximum chord-error Ermax.

sec.title: 4 VELOCITY PLANNING
sec.p: After the tool-path preprocessing, short continuous line segments may exist in the tool-path, i.e. the tool-path may become a mixed path: short NURBS curves mixed with continuous line segments. Hence, the velocity planning will become more complex. After a comprehensive consideration, the following parts are indispensable.

sec.title: 4.1 The velocity planning of a single NURBS curve
sec.p: The three-step velocity planning method [9] is used for a simple continuous NURBS curve. First, adaptive-feed rate method is used. The first velocity planning of NURBS curve is computed according to the curvature limitation conditions, which can keep the chord-error within a tolerance range. The velocity VEr corresponding to the chord-error is (10) where ri is the radius of curvature at ui, Eri the value of the chord-error, and Ts the sampling time. The final velocity V(ui) at ui can be determined by the following formula (11) where Vmax is the allowed maximum velocity.

Second, the velocity sensitive corner will be detected according to the first velocity planning results, and theaccelerating curve segments, decelerating curve segments and curve segments with uniform velocity will be identified. Then, the new starting and ending points of acceleration/deceleration blocks are determined, and the velocity planning results will be modified to make the acceleration/deceleration limited within the capacity of the machine tool.

Third, final modification will be done to discard all undesired results, like intersection or discontinuous of the velocity curve, and so on, to make the final velocity curve continuous without chattering. Besides, there is only one velocity value corresponding to the given curve parameter.

sec.title: 4.2 The velocity planning of small line segments
sec.p: Short continuous line segments composed of 3D points form an approximated curve. The velocity planning is determining every allowed maximum velocity of these points. In addition, one velocity planning method named look-ahead [14] will be used. The velocity of a point on curve will be computed by some limitation conditions.

The look-ahead number and the initial value of starting and ending velocities should be set first. Inaddition, the allowed maximum starting and ending velocities are not zero but a value computed by several limitations as below (12) where Vi-1end is the maximum ending velocity of the previous NURBS curve, Vi+1st the maximum starting velocity of the next NURBS curve, θi the intersection angle of NURBS curve and small continuous line segments, and Viθ the velocity limited by θi.

sec.title: 4.3 The velocity planning of mixed path
sec.p:
There are several combining forms of three adjacentcurves on the mixed path, as shown in Fig. 5. The boldface represents the current curve, and the curves connected by the straight lines are the adjacent curves. The left curve is the curve before the current curve, and the right one is the curve after it. The number −1 represents the starting or the ending of the curve. Fig. 5
The combination forms of the tool-path

Velocity at joint point is the minimum of the following three velocities: the maximum ending velocity of the first curve, the maximum starting velocity of the second curve, and the angle limit velocity (13)

If the current curve is the starting curve, the starting velocity limitation will be set to zero; or if the current curve is the ending curve, the ending velocity limitation will be set to zero. And the program flow chart of velocity planning for mixed-path are shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 6
Program flow chart of velocity planning for mixed-path

sec.title: 5 INTERPOLATION ALGORITHM
sec.p: Interpolation is an inverse operation, the curve length S can be computed from the V–t curve by integral operation, and then the interpolation point P0 related to the time domain can be obtained from the relationship between length and curve (14)

Integral period is an important issue, which has to be handled carefully. As shown in Fig. 7, it is not an integral period point when the velocity is V2, where V2 is the end velocity of one velocity segment, t0 the rest of the time, and S0 the rest of the length. Fig. 7
The problem of integral period

A simplified calculation formula for the interpolation points on the joint of the two velocity segments isused in this article. The velocity segments can beacceleration segment, deceleration segment, or constant speed segment.

If t0 < ts, the rest time t0 of this velocity segment will be compensated at the next velocity segment, i.e. the first integral time of the next velocity segment is equal to ts - t0, and the time t0 can be computed by the following formula.
Case 1: The current velocity segment is acceleration segment
(15)
Case 2 : The current velocity segment is deceleration segment
(16)
Case 3 : The current velocity segment is constant speed segment
(17)
If t0 = ts, integral time requires no compensation.

sec.title: 6.1 Simulation results
sec.p:
A discontinuous NURBS curve in 2D space is named Example 1, as shown in Fig. 8. Fig. 8
The 2D discontinuous NURBS curve (Example 1): (a) the velocity curves and (b) the acceleration curves

The associated parameters of this curve are: the path length is 90.9083 mm; the degree of NURBS curve is 3; the interpolation period is Ts = 0.002 s; the maximum feed rate command is Vmax = 58 mm/s; the feed acceleration is Amax = 500 mm/s2; The look-ahead number of continuous line segments is: Nt = 10; and the minimum splitting length is Smin=Vmax 2/Amax=582/500mm=6.728mm.

In the traditional method, the whole curve will be approximated by short continuous line segments, and a linear interpolator will be applied for the cusps on the NURBS curve. Comparatively, the algorithm proposed in this article can deal with this kind of curve directly. It will be further illustrated by the following results.

The simulation results are shown in Fig. 9. The velocity curves are shown in Fig. 9(a), and the acceleration curves in Fig. 9(b). The first curve of each figure is the result when applying linear interpolator, while the second one is the result when applying real-time NURBS curve interpolator. Fig. 9
The simulation results (Example 1)

The machining time when applying the real-time NURBS interpolator is shorter than linear interpolator. The velocity curve is smoother when applying the real-time NURBS interpolator, and the change of acceleration is not so frequent as well.

A mixed path in 2D space is named Example 2, as shown in Fig. 10. The shape of this mixed path looks like a butterfly, which is composed of four NURBS curves and one continuous line segment. The fourth NURBS curve has four cusps, and the curve length between the first and the second cusps is short, as well as the length between the third and the fourth cusps. Hence, these two segments NURBS curve will be approximated by continuous line segments. Fig. 10
The mixed-path in 2D space (Example 2): (a)the velocity curves and (b) the acceleration curves

The associated parameters of the 2D mixed path are: the path length is 1435.04 mm; the number of curve 6 (4 NURBS curves + 1 continuous line segment + 1 NURBS curve); the degree of NURBS curve is 2; the interpolation period is Ts = 0.002 s; the maximum feed rate command is Vmax = 25 mm/s; the feed acceleration is Amax = 300 mm/s2; the look-ahead number is Nt = 10; and the minimum splitting length is Smin=Vmax 2/Amax=252/300mm=2.083mm.

As the traditional NURBS curve interpolator cannot deal with mixed path, the mixed path will be approximated by short continuous line segments first, andthen the linear interpolator will be applied. The following results are the comparison of the two interpolators.

The simulation results are shown in Fig. 11. And the same conclusion can be summarized as in Example 1: The machining time is shorter; The velocity curve is smoother and the change of acceleration is smoother as well. Fig. 11
The simulation results (Example 2)

There is another example of mixed path in 3D space, as shown in Fig. 12, which is a tool-path created by CAM system, named as Example 3. In addition, the associated parameters of the mixed path are: the path length is 33670.62mm; the degree of NURBS curve is 3; the interpolation period isTs = 0.002 s; the maximum feed rate command isVmax = 58 mm/s; the feed acceleration is Amax = 500 mm/s2; the look-ahead number is Nt = 10; and the minimum splitting length isSmin=Vmax 2/Amax=582/500=6.728(mm). Fig. 12
The mixed-path in 3D space (Example 3): (a) the velocity curves and (b) the acceleration curves

As this mixed path is too long, it is not suitable for the results analysis, and part of the whole mixed path is intercepted. The velocity and acceleration curves of the intercepted path are shown in Fig. 13. In addition, the same conclusion can be summarized as in example. Fig. 13
The simulation results (Example 3)

sec.title: 6.2 Experiment results
sec.p:
In order to verify the practical application of this real-time NURBS interpolator, an experimental system with three-axis CNC system is used to perform the real machining, and the experiment platform is shown in Fig. 14. Fig. 14
Three-axis CNC system for the experiment: (a) linear interpolator and (b) real-time NURBS interpolator

The machine tool is shown in the left figure. Inaddition, the controller used is the GUC of Googoltech. The relevant parameters of this controller are a X86 architecture (600 MHz) processor, a PCI communication, and eight-axis controller. Besides, the terminal board is taken as a transmission port, as shown in the bottom right corner.

The machining results of Example 2 are shown as in Fig. 15, where the figure on the left is the machining results when applying linear interpolator, as shown in Fig. 15(a), and the figure on the right is the machining results when applying real-time NURBS curve interpolator, as shown in Fig. 15(b). Fig. 15
Machining results when two interpolators of Example 2 were applied

By comparing the above machining results, it is found that they are almost the same when the machining segments are approximated straight line,but when the curvature becomes larger, the better result when applying the real-time NURBS interpolator can be seen obviously. It can be seen that the smoothness is nearly perfect when applying real-time NURBS interpolator. However, when the curvature is large, trace of vibration is obvious when applying linear interpolator.

Besides, the machine tool works smoother whenapplying the real-time NURBS interpolator. In addition, the machine tool vibration when applying real-time NURBS interpolator is less than that when applying linear interpolator. In order to verify this point, a laser scanning vibrometer is used to test the vibration of machine tool. The experiment platform is shown in Fig. 16, and the laser light emitted by the laser scanning vibrometer is aimed at the machine tool body. When the vibration of machine tool occurs, the positional shifts of machine tool body will be transformed to velocity information, the velocities of positional shifts have some correspondence with the output voltage, and the relationship between the vibration velocity and output voltage is 5 m/s ∼ 1 V. In addition, an oscilloscope is used for the voltage signal acquisition and the observing of vibration velocity. Fig. 16
The laser scanning vibrometer: (a) the vibration curve when linear interpolator is applied and (b) the vibration curve when real-time NURBS interpolator is applied

The vibration curve for the two cases is shown in Fig. 17, where Fig. 17(a) shows the vibration curve when applying linear interpolator, and Fig. 17(b) shows the vibration curve when applying real-time mixed-path interpolator. In addition, the abscissa axis of oscilloscope is time, one grid is 4 s; and vertical axis is the output voltage of the laser scanning vibrometer, one grid is 1 mV. It can be seen obviously that the vibration of machine tool body is more severe when linear interpolator is applied, the maximum size of the vibrations is 3.78 mV, the corresponding maximum vibration velocity is 0.029 m/s, and when applying real-time NURBS interpolator the size is 0.720 mV, the corresponding maximum vibration velocity is 0.0036 m/s. Fig. 17
The vibration curve when two interpolators were applied

The time for computing and machining of three examples is listed in Table 1. Table 1
The time for computing and machining of three examples
Linear interpolator Mixed-path interpolator
Compute time (s) Machining time (s) Compute time (s) Machining time (s)
Example 1 0.5160 4.5740 1.3590 3.4150
Example 2 0.6090 73.8600 2.0780 60.2080
Example 3 58.4990 1262.4550 198.7660 800.698

It can be seen that the computing time of linear interpolator is shorter than NURBS interpolator, and the average ratio is 0.3223. However, the machining time of linear interpolator is longer than NURBS interpolator, and the average ratio is 1.3809. The algorithm efficiency of real-time NURBS interpolator is lower than the linear interpolator, but the machining efficiency has an obvious improvement. In addition, the computing time is much less than the machining time, which satisfies the real-time requirement.

sec.title: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: NURBS curve interpolator has become one of themost important techniques in CNC machining. A practical and efficient real-time NURBS curve interpolator is crucial to support the development of modern intelligent CNC controllers.

In this article, a practical real-time NURBS curve interpolator was developed for various NURBS curves. The curve splitting of the NURBS curve is used, and two disposal modules and data buffer are used to realize real-time operation. This algorithm handles not only a continuous NURBS curve real-time, but also a discontinuous NURBS curve or the tool-path composed with NURBS curves and short continuous line segments.

There are three advantages of this real-time NURBS curve: first, a real-time NURBS curve interpolator is designed from a new perspective in the sense that the curve splitting and two disposal modules are working at the same time; second, the whole tool-path is considered, instead of only a single NURBS curve; and third, the discontinuous case of a NURBS curve is considered.

This real-time NURBS curve interpolator has the following advantages over linear interpolator. From the view of the smoothness of the machined surface, the interpolation points of real-time NURSB interpolator are all on the designed path, except the curve which has been as approximated by line segments due to the curve length; so, the machined surface quality with the real-time NURBS interpolator is higher than that with the linear interpolator. From the view of the capacity of the machine tool, the velocity fluctuation of the real-time mixed path interpolator is much smaller than linear interpolator; so, the change of acceleration is not that much frequent as linear interpolator. The stability of the mixed path interpolator is guaranteed, and the vibration of the machine tool is much smaller. From the view of machining efficiency, the machining time with the real-time mixed-path interpolator is shorter than that with linear interpolator.
Both the simulation and practical tests have proved the effectiveness of the proposed practical real-time NURBS interpolator.
